titleStmt.title: Letter from Sir Leslie Stephen to Thomas Hardy (H.5498)

supportDesc.support: Autograph letter signed, two written pages on a single bifolium, with one additional blank side; cream laid paper in brown ink, in a small cursive hand.

div.p:
I am sorry that I shall not be able to expect a story from
you at an earlier date. I do not however mean
to fix any particular time, as we are generally going
to remain away four months.
At present I may say that we shall probably have room
for a new story somewhere about October or November
next. I expect a new story to begin in January to
last till about that time. If that should
be too early for you, there will probably be one
a few months later.
If you would give me a call when you come to town
I should be very glad to see you to talk about
our future arrangements which will probably be clearer by
that time than they now are.
Meanwhile I should extremely be anxious to have the
refusal of your play if you can give it me. From
what you say, I think it would suit us very well.

I may however say that I think that I could, if you desired
it, make an arrangement to that effect, viz. that you
should write the story with a view to the The Cornhill, but
that Messrs Smith & Elder should understand that if they
did not use it for that purpose, they should publish
it independently. I suggest this in order that you
might not be going out of your way by writing
expressly for us, with any doubt as to your story
being then possibly thrown away.
I do not think, however, from what you say, that such an
arrangement would be necessary, as I fancy that your
novel would most likely suit us independently of
any special intention as to its ultimate destination.
I may add that I should not think it at all necessary to
have the whole story written in advance, unless that
mode of publishing was more convenient to you. Of
course it is more convenient to be in possession of
the whole Ms; but most authors are in the habit
of publishing the first part before having come to the
end.
My present address is as above. I shall be changing my house in
the spring; but a note to Smith, Elder, 15
Waterloo Place, London
will always find me in a day or two.
